Name: Cuneiform Tablet Letter
Description: Clay tablets were used for diplomatic correspondence between the Egyptian court and the rulers of the neighboring Asiatic states and city-states. The writing is cuneiform, a script generally used in the Near East at that time. The text was pressed into wet clay with a wedge-shaped stylus and the tablet was then fired. The letter was covered with a clay envelope and a seal that would be broken by the recipient. Several hundreds of these tablets were discovered in the archives of the king's palace at Tell el-Amarna. This tablet is a letter sent by Kadashman Enlil the First to Amenhotep the Third. It says, "As to my own daughter, about whom you have written to marry, she is grown up and now marriageable, send for her."
